Data.Name: Character Escapes
Data.Description: Escape characters that signal to the regular expression parser that the character

Elements.Name: Bell
Elements.Description: Matches a bell (alarm) \u0007.

Elements.Name: Backspace
Elements.Description: Matches a backspace \u0008 if in a [] character class

Elements.Name: Tab
Elements.Description: Matches a tab \u0009.

Elements.Name: Carriage return
Elements.Description: Matches a carriage return \u000D. Note that a new line is made up of \r\n (CRLF)

Elements.Name: Vertical tab
Elements.Description: Matches a tab \u0009.

Elements.Name: Form feed
Elements.Description: Matches a form feed \u000C.

Elements.Name: New line
Elements.Description: Matches a new line \u000A. Note that a new line is made up of \r\n (CRLF) on Windows systems.

Elements.Name: Escape
Elements.Description: Matches an escape \u001B.

Elements.Name: ASCII character as Octal
Elements.Description: Matches an ASCII character as octal (up to three digits); numbers with no leading zero are backreferences if they have only one digit or if they correspond to a capturing group number. (For more information, see Backreferences.) For example, the character \040 represents a space.

Elements.Name: ASCII character as Hex
Elements.Description: Matches an ASCII character using hexadecimal representation (exactly two digits).

Elements.Name: Control character
Elements.Description: Matches an ASCII control character; for example, \cC is control-C.

Elements.Name: Unicode character
Elements.Description: Matches a Unicode character using hexadecimal representation (exactly four digits)

Data.Name: Character Classes
Data.Description: The set of regular expression characters that define the substring to match.

Elements.Name: Any character
Elements.Description: Matches any character except \n. If modified by the Singleline option, a period character matches any character.

Elements.Name: Any character in set
Elements.Description: Matches any single character included in the specified set of characters.

Elements.Name: Any character not in set
Elements.Description: Matches any single character not in the specified set of characters.

Elements.Name: Character ranges
Elements.Description: Use of a hyphen (–) allows specification of contiguous character ranges.

Elements.Name: Unicode group
Elements.Description: Matches text not included in groups and block ranges specified in {name}.

Elements.Name: Not in Unicode group
Elements.Description: Matches text not included in groups and block ranges specified in {name}.

Elements.Name: Any word character
Elements.Description: Matches any word character. Equivalent to the Unicode character categories [\p{Ll}\p{Lu}\p{Lt}\p{Lo}\p{Nd}\p{Pc}]. If ECMAScript-compliant behavior is specified with the ECMAScript option, \w is equivalent to [a-zA-Z_0-9].

Elements.Name: Non-word character
Elements.Description: Matches any nonword character. Equivalent to the Unicode categories [^\p{Ll}\p{Lu}\p{Lt}\p{Lo}\p{Nd}\p{Pc}]. If ECMAScript-compliant behavior is specified with the ECMAScript option, \W is equivalent to [^a-zA-Z_0-9].

Elements.Name: White-space character
Elements.Description: Matches any white-space character. Equivalent to the Unicode character categories [\f\n\r\t\v\x85\p{Z}]. If ECMAScript-compliant behavior is specified with the ECMAScript option, \s is equivalent to [ \f\n\r\t\v].

Elements.Name: Non-white-space character
Elements.Description: Matches any non-white-space character. Equivalent to the Unicode character categories [^\f\n\r\t\v\x85\p{Z}]. If ECMAScript-compliant behavior is specified with the ECMAScript option, \S is equivalent to [^ \f\n\r\t\v].

Elements.Name: Digit
Elements.Description: Matches any decimal digit. Equivalent to \p{Nd} for Unicode and [0-9] for non-Unicode, ECMAScript behavior.

Elements.Name: Non-digit
Elements.Description: Matches any nondigit. Equivalent to \P{Nd} for Unicode and [^0-9] for non-Unicode, ECMAScript behavior.

Data.Name: Atomic Zero-Width Assertions
Data.Description: Assertions that cause a match to succeed or fail depending on the regular expression parser's current position in the input string.

Elements.Name: Match start of string
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the beginning of the string or the beginning of the line. For more information, see the Multiline option.

Elements.Name: Match end of string
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the end of the string, before \n at the end of the string, or at the end of the line.

Elements.Name: Match start of string (ignore Multiline)
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the beginning of the string (ignores the Multiline option).

Elements.Name: Match before end of string (ignore Multiline)
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the end of the string or before \n at the end of the string (ignores the Multiline option).

Elements.Name: Match end of string (ignore multiline)
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the end of the string (ignores the Multiline option).

Elements.Name: Match where previous match ended
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur at the point where the previous match ended. When used with Match.NextMatch(), this ensures that matches are all contiguous.

Elements.Name: Boundary
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must occur on a boundary between \w (alphanumeric) and \W (nonalphanumeric) characters. The match must occur on word boundaries — that is, at the first or last characters in words separated by any nonalphanumeric characters.

Elements.Name: Non-boundary
Elements.Description: Specifies that the match must not occur on a \b boundary.

Data.Name: Quantifiers
Data.Description: Optional quantifiers that modify a regular expression.

Elements.Name: Zero or more matches
Elements.Description: Specifies zero or more matches; for example, \w* or (abc)*. Equivalent to {0,}.

Elements.Name: One or more matches
Elements.Description: Specifies one or more matches; for example, \w+ or (abc)+. Equivalent to {1,}.

Elements.Name: Zero or one matches
Elements.Description: Specifies zero or one matches; for example, \w? or (abc)?. Equivalent to {0,1}.

Elements.Name: Exactly n matches
Elements.Description: Specifies exactly n matches; for example, (pizza){2}.

Elements.Name: At least n matches
Elements.Description: Specifies at least n matches; for example, (abc){2,}.

Elements.Name: At least n and no more than m matches
Elements.Description: Specifies at least n matches; for example, (abc){2,}.

Elements.Name: First match with few repeats as possible
Elements.Description: Specifies the first match that consumes as few repeats as possible (equivalent to lazy *).

Elements.Name: As few repeats but at least one
Elements.Description: Specifies as few repeats as possible, but at least one (equivalent to lazy +).

Elements.Name: Zero repeats if possible
Elements.Description: Specifies zero repeats if possible, or one (lazy ?).

Elements.Name: Lazy {n}
Elements.Description: Equivalent to {n} (lazy {n}).

Elements.Name: Lazy {n}
Elements.Description: Specifies as few repeats as possible, but at least n (lazy {n,}).

Elements.Name: Lazy [n,m}
Elements.Description: Specifies as few repeats as possible between n and m (lazy {n,m}).

Data.Name: Grouping Constructs
Data.Description: Grouping constructs that cause a regular expression to capture groups of subexpressions.

Elements.Name: Group
Elements.Description: Captures the matched substring. Captures using () are numbered automatically based on the order of the opening parenthesis, starting from one. The first capture, capture element number zero, is the text matched by the whole regular expression pattern.

Elements.Name: Named group
Elements.Description: Captures the matched substring into a group name or number name. The string used for name must not contain any punctuation and it cannot begin with a number. You can use single quotes instead of angle brackets; for example, (?'name').

Elements.Name: Balancing group
Elements.Description: Balancing group definition. Deletes the definition of the previously defined group name2 and stores in group name1 the interval between the previously defined name2 group and the current group. If no group name2 is defined, the match backtracks. Because deleting the last definition of name2 reveals the previous definition of name2, this construct allows the stack of captures for group name2 to be used as a counter for keeping track of nested constructs such as parentheses. In this construct, name1 is optional. You can use single quotes instead of angle brackets; for example, (?'name1-name2').

Elements.Name: Non-capturing group
Elements.Description: Non-capturing group.

Elements.Name: Positive lookahead
Elements.Description: Zero-width positive lookahead assertion. Continues match only if the subexpression matches at this position on the right. For example, \w+(?=\d) matches a word followed by a digit, without matching the digit. This construct does not backtrack.

Elements.Name: Negative lookahead
Elements.Description: Zero-width negative lookahead assertion. Continues match only if the subexpression does not matches at this position on the right. For example, \b(?!un)\w+\b matches a word that do not begin with un.

Elements.Name: Positive lookbehind
Elements.Description: Zero-width positive lookbehind assertion. Continues match only if the subexpression matches at this position on the left. For example, (?<=19)99 matches instances of 99 that follow 19. This construct does not backtrack.

Elements.Name: Negative lookbehind
Elements.Description: Zero-width negative lookbehind assertion. Continues match only if the subexpression does not match at the position on the left.

Elements.Name: Nonbacktracking subexpression
Elements.Description: Nonbacktracking subexpression (also known as a "greedy" subexpression). The subexpression is fully matched once, and then does not participate piecemeal in backtracking. (That is, the subexpression matches only strings that would be matched by the subexpression alone.)

Elements.Name: Backreference
Elements.Description: Backreference. For example, (\w)\1 finds doubled word characters.

Elements.Name: Named backreference
Elements.Description: Named backreference. For example, (?<char>\w)\k<char> finds doubled word characters. The expression (?<43>\w)\43 does the same. You can use single quotes instead of angle brackets; for example, \k'char'.

Data.Name: Alternation Constructs
Data.Description: Modifies a regular expression to allow either/or matching.

Elements.Name: Or
Elements.Description: Matches any one of the terms separated by the | (vertical bar) character; for example, cat|dog|tiger. The leftmost successful match wins.

Elements.Name: Conditional
Elements.Description: Matches the "yes" part if the expression matches at this point; otherwise, matches the "no" part. The "no" part can be omitted. The expression can be any valid subexpression, but it is turned into a zero-width assertion, so this syntax is equivalent to (?(?=expression)yes|no). Note that if the expression is the name of a named group or a capturing group number, the alternation construct is interpreted as a capture test (described in the next row of this table). To avoid confusion in these cases, you can spell out the inside (?=expression) explicitly.

Elements.Name: Capture test
Elements.Description: Matches the "yes" part if the named capture string has a match; otherwise, matches the "no" part. The "no" part can be omitted. If the given name does not correspond to the name or number of a capturing group used in this expression, the alternation construct is interpreted as an expression test (described in the preceding row of this table).

Data.Name: Miscellaneous Constructs
Data.Description: Miscellaneous constructs that modify regular expression matching behavior.

Elements.Name: Comment
Elements.Description: Inline comment inserted within a regular expression. The comment terminates at the first closing parenthesis character.

Elements.Name: Single line comment
Elements.Description: X-mode comment. The comment begins at an unescaped # and continues to the end of the line. (Note that the x option or the RegexOptions.IgnorePatternWhitespace enumerated option must be activated for this kind of comment to be recognized.)

Data.Name: Options
Data.Description: Options to change regular expression behaviour.

Elements.Name: IgnoreCase On
Elements.Description: Enables case-insensitive matching.

Elements.Name: IgnoreCase Off
Elements.Description: Disables case-insensitive matching.

Elements.Name: Multiline On
Elements.Description: Enables multiline mode. Changes the meaning of ^ and $ so that they match at the beginning and end, respectively, of any line, not just the beginning and end of the whole string.

Elements.Name: Multiline Off
Elements.Description: Disables multiline mode.

Elements.Name: ExplicitCapture On
Elements.Description: Specifies that the only valid captures are explicitly named or numbered groups of the form (?<name>…). This allows parentheses to act as noncapturing groups without the syntactic clumsiness of (?:…).

Elements.Name: ExplicitCapture Off
Elements.Description: Disables explicit capturing of groups.

Elements.Name: Singleline On
Elements.Description: Enables single-line mode. Changes the meaning of the period character (.) so that it matches every character (instead of every character except \n).

Elements.Name: Singleline Off
Elements.Description: Disables single-line mode.

Elements.Name: IgnorePatternWhitespace On
Elements.Description: Enables that unescaped white space is excluded from the pattern and enables comments following a number sign (#). (For a list of escaped white-space characters, see Character Escapes.) Note that white space is never eliminated from within a character class.

Elements.Name: IgnorePatternWhitespace Off
Elements.Description: Disables that unescaped white space is excluded from the pattern and disables comments following a number sign (#).
